subject: Testing Client/Server

messageBody:
Hi everyone,
 
I am writing testcases for a Client/Server system. I am testing if the messages added by Client are actually added to the server.
 
I have a code where the Client application adds a message to the Server, now server (which is though local on my machine) may take sometime to receive that message. I make another object of Client(say Client II ) and asks this client to get the messages from the server. This is done to test whether messages are being added to the server by Client-I. Server never responds to the client which adds the message to it. So it is neccessary to have another Client listening if the message has been added to the server.
 
But my tests fail as the Client II created to listen to the messages added by Client-I doesnot get messages due to time some time delay in adding and retreiving the messages. I cannot specify any time frame in which a message may be received. (though i tried putting a dealy of say 100 milliseconds, but this does not work all time, as sometime it may take about 100/200/500 milliseconds for the message to be added to the server). So i cannot depend on time delay.
 
Please let me know if you have ideas to test such a system.
 
Manpreet

Subject: Re: [junit] RE: [XP] Need Advice on Unit Testing Pain

Hi Alain,

  I suggest you use the method getTableWithID() of HTTPUnit. Very powerfull
in helping the tests to survive layout changes. Want it or not, HTML Tables
are the way layout gets done, so you can excpect tens of tables to be added
to your pages in the "make it super nice" phase. This method enables you to
esealy find a table marked like this:

<TABLE ID=errorMessages>

so you can easily do assertEquals( 0,
response.getTableWithId("errorMessages).getRowCount())

and code other fancy methods like

checkPageReturnedOkWithoutErrorMessages(reponse);
assertProductNumbersInCart(response,new String [] {"48","72","32",45"} );

and so on...

But I do share your pain. One of the major selling point of the web
development is fast feature addition and fast UI design/modification. All
that speed makes it hard for extensive web feature testing to follow the
pace. I think the trick is to be as uniform as possible accross the site.
This helps testing by sharing handing testing methods for all test cases and
by modifying only theses methods when an inevitable major change happens. It
is also good for the user experience to be uniform anyway.

mathieu

Paul,

Let me share my "experience" on - bad - web testing pain reaction :

>>> De : Paul Hodgetts [mailto:prh@...]
>>> Recently, developers have stopped writing these web tests,
>>> resorting to running the tests manually by hand.
>>> .. We're having trouble reaching consensus. ..
>>> If so, should the tests be automated?  IMHO, they should for
>>> all the same reasons we automate any tests.


A few months ago, I discovered httpUnit.

Oh joy. I quickly developped a few test cases :
   - test_loginSuccess ()
   - test_loginFailure ()
   - test_forgotPassword ()
   - test_clickOnHelpButtong ()
...


Easy, powerfull, and a real help. Couldn't live without it.


BUT,
  after changing the HTML layout,
  and adding complexity to the pages,
  and adding pages to the application,
  and running out of time,
I gave up on automated web testing : too much pain, to keep the tests
up to date.

AND,
as I had extracted most of the logic, and the DB related functionalities
out of the servlets, I could build useful tests with straight junit.
...


THEN
something happened with CVS, and some new code got overwritten by some old
code.
...

BUT,
I didn't notice, because it was used in some rare cases, in problems I had
solved a
long time ago - a few weeks ago -.
...


The day before the demo to the client, I ran a comprehensive manual
test of the whole application : 25 minutes, to try out most of the case.
Then I noticed something was wrong.
But it was too late, because it had happenend a month before I noticed.
...


LAST WEEK
I started building a simple layer based on httpUnit that goes like this :

public void test_homePage ()
  {
     PageChecker homePage = new PageChecker
("http://www.here.com/index.html") ;

     homePage
        .titleIs   (Op.EQUALS_IGNORECASE, "welcome")
        .nofTables (2)                   // contains 2 tables
        .nofForm   (Op.MIN, 1)     ;     // contains at least 1 form

     TableChecker table0 =  homePage.getTable(0);
     table0
        .nofColumns (2)
        .nofRows    (2)
        .hasCellWithText (0,0, Op.START_WITH, "your name")      ;

     TableChecker innerTable =  table0.getTableInCell (0,1) ;

      ...

     assertAllChecksAreTrue (homePage) ;
  }

I have this feeling I'm reinventing the wheel, but I was fun to write.

NEXT WEEK, I think I'm goint go write a simple html parsing tool,
that writes the java test code for me, so I can cut and paste it
into my code, and adapt it.

Just my story.


Alain Ravet
Brussels, Belgium




-----Message d'origine-----
De : Paul Hodgetts [mailto:prh@...]
Recently, developers have stopped writing these web tests,
resorting to running the tests manually by hand.  Their
reasoning is that the cost of writing the web tests is not
justified by their benefits.  Others point out the issues
with manual tests (inconsistent tests, the extra time to run
them repeatedly, lack of documentation, etc.), and assert
that the tests are worth the admittedly high costs.  We're
having trouble reaching consensus.

If so, should the tests be automated?  IMHO, they should for
all the same reasons we automate any tests.
